除非你居住在世界上或某个国家的一个永远都是夏天的地方，要不你都很可能有好几个月不能打高尔夫球或网球。
But this process is cumbersome both for the writers, who have to constantly upload new reports, and for the readers who are perpetually refreshing the page.
但是这整个过程无论是对于作者（需要不间断的上传报道）还是读者（需要不停的刷新页面）来说都是很繁复的。

ex: n. 恢复；复苏；回升；痊愈
网络 复原；回收；康复
eg2: My father has made a full recovery from the operation.
我父亲手术后已完全康复了。
to make a remarkable/quick/speedy/slow, etc. recovery
恢复显著、很快、迅速、缓慢等
She is on the road to(= making progress towards) recovery .
她正在康复之中。
The government is forecasting an economic recovery .
政府预测经济会复苏。
a recovery in consumer spending
消费支出的回升
The economy is showing signs of recovery.
经济呈现出复苏的迹象。
There is a reward for information leading to the recovery of the missing diamonds.
凡能为找回丢失的钻石提供线索者可获奖赏。

ex: n. 奢侈品；奢华；奢侈的享受；不常有的乐趣（或享受、优势）
adj. 奢华的
网络 豪华；豪华型；华贵
eg2: Now we'll be able to live in luxury for the rest of our lives.
如今我们可在有生之年过豪华生活了。
to lead a life of luxury
过奢侈的生活
a luxury hotel
豪华酒店
luxury goods
奢侈品
small luxuries like chocolate and flowers
像巧克力和鲜花之类的小奢侈品
I love having a long, hot bath─it's one of life's little luxuries .
我喜欢在热水浴缸里多泡一会儿，这是生活里一种小小的享受。
It was a luxury if you had a washing machine in those days.
那时候有洗衣机就算是奢侈了。
We had the luxury of being able to choose from four good candidates for the job.
我们的挑选余地大，有四位出色的职位候选人可供选择。

ex: vi. （搭乘车、船等）通勤；代偿
vt. 减刑；交换；用……交换；使……变成
n. 通勤（口语）
eg2: Leaving the car at home and sharing your commute with others can help you reach your gallon goal very quickly.
把汽车在家里和与其他人分享您的通勤，可以帮助您很快达到一加仑的目标。
Show your boss the quantifiable results upon returning, and tell him or her that — without all the distractions, , etc. — you can get twice as much done.
回来后，向老板展示可量化的结果；告诉他/她，要是没有那些分心的事、通勤等等耽搁的话，你可以做现在两倍的活。
If jobs require people to  a great distance or to move themselves to another state, or to another hemisphere, employers may find they need to sweeten their offers.
如果提供的工作要求雇员通勤很长的距离或者搬家到另一个州或另一个半球，那么雇主则会发觉他们应该提供更丰厚的待遇。

ex: n. 次要情节；陪衬情节

the delicate arch of her eyebrows
她那弯弯的柳眉

猫弓起背发出嘶嘶声。
Tall trees arched over the path.
大树呈拱形遮阴了小道。
an arch tone of voice
调皮的语气

ex: v. 突袭；偷袭；突击搜捕；突然搜查
n. 抢劫；突然袭击；突击检查；突然搜查

eg2: They carried out a bombing raid on enemy bases.
他们突然出击，轰炸了敌军的基地。

an armed bank raid
一起持械抢劫银行案

边境附近的村庄经常遭受突袭。
a raiding party(= a group of soldiers, etc. that attack a place)
突袭小分队
Many treasures were lost when the tombs were raided in the last century.
上世纪这些坟墓遭到偷盗，很多财宝都失踪了。
I caught him raiding the fridge again(= taking food from it) .
我撞见他又在扫荡冰箱里的食物。

ex: vt. 共鸣；共振
vi. 共鸣；共振

根本没有共鸣。
Pick one program, course or mentor you resonate with and stick with it.
选择一个方案、课程或与你有共鸣的良师益友，并坚持下去。
A child reared in a family of musicians may all his／her life resonate to song and dance.
在音乐世家里养大的孩子可能一生之中对歌舞都有共鸣。

ex: n. 场地；会场；(体育)场馆；集合地点

而布什，在飞机撞击双子星塔的时候，给一群小孩子们念“可爱的小山羊”的事情，将永远被装订在历史的耻辱柱上。
In shopping malls, Sweden's pay-to-pee public toilets are often unisex to minimize those infamously long lines for women's bathrooms (a minus: men still leave the seat up!).

ex: 网络 紧急；系统不可用；紧急情况(Emergencies)

If change is  in your household, then try and follow these tips and lets see if we can make the change easier and better for all.
如果你家里这个转变即将来临，要试着遵循这些小技巧，然后看看我们是否能使这个转变变得更容易更好。
As the impact of the imminent Great Disruption hits us, he says, “our response will be proportionally dramatic, mobilizing as we do in war.
当即将来临的大崩解的冲击殃及我们时，他说：“我们的反应也将相应地巨大，如同我们在战争中做的那样动员起来。

the renewal date

ex: n. 寂寞；孤独感；孤单；孤寂

eg2: Her findings have helped to transform conventional ideas about how the brain starts to deteriorate once we reach our teenage years.
她的发现有助于转变我们通常的观念——一旦渡过青少年时期之后，我们的大脑便开始走向恶化。
“The goal is to do a scan on someone before they get the disease and be able to tell if they’re at higher risk or starting to , ” she said.
“我们的目标是在某人患上老年痴呆病之前， 对他的脑部进行扫描，从而预先告知他们是否处于较高疾病风险或情况开始恶化，”她说。
We know that a form of selection occurs within our brains as we develop and learn - synaptic connections and pathways that work well are reinforced, whereas weak ones .
我们知道，人在发育和学习期间大脑里面发生一种形式的选择——那些运转正常的突触链接和路径得到加强，而弱者恶化。

ex: n. 离开；出发；违背

问题可以包括：你离开后会有什么样的影响？

然而，另外一个大脑系统常常变得更加活跃，当抗议它们情人的离开时：生气。
Travellers who have in the past received three or more doses of OPV should be offered another dose of polio vaccine before .

, the project will mainly focus on Java, where most of the human deaths have occurred.

title: “Absolute Hell” is a eulogy for “third places”
content: Absolute Hell” is a eulogy for third places”” Rodney Ackland’s play, recently revive, explores the freedoms and the fragility of 1940s London IN 1989 Ray Oldenburg, an American sociologist, explored the idea of the third place” Life, he argued, has always been experienced in one of three settings: the home, the workplace or a third place” such as high streets, coffeehouse and pubs. These venue are neutral, largely free from the economic pressures of the office and the domestic pressures of the home. Mr Oldenburg considered these spaces to be the heart of the community and necessary to any healthy democracy: he worried that the suburbs emerg on the edges of American cities would lead to isolation and polarisation as people commute by car, frequenting these places and interacting with their neighbours less. A third place is at the heart of Absolute Hell” Rodney Ackland’s play, a new production of which has recently started at the National Theatre in London. Hugh Marriner (Charle Edwards) is fighting—and losing—a war on two fronts. He is trying to rescue a dying writing career: a critic has eviscerate his short stories, and nobody seems to have the time or the inclination to read his screenplay. Meanwhile, his closeted lover has tire of his drinking and decide to get married. The walls seem to be closing in. Marriner’s crisis plays out in La Vie en Rose, a fictional drinking club in London’s Soho district. It is the summer of 1945: the fighting in Europe is over, the city is in ruins, the streets are heav with refugees and a radical Labour government is imminent. Over the course of the play, 24 characters bounce off each other at what appears to be the social epicentre of the metropolis. Soldiers, artists, socialists and prostitute flow through the bar where they are confronte by the frenetic Marriner and Christine Foskett (Kate Fleetwood) the club’s congenial host. Between them, Marriner and Foskett hold the wide and spasmodic subplots together as they absorb and externalise the chaos unfold around them. Marriner feels safe among friends, and almost seems to enjoy discussing his dysfunctional love life and his moribund career with them. But when his exasperate lover and his arch critic penetrate the walls of La Vie en Rose, his temperament immediately deteriorate. He breaks into tears as his former boyfriend denounce Marriner’s life of drinking, smoking and debt, reject his queer lifestyle as a sexual disability” These are the moments when the third place cease to be a third place, and dissolve back into the rigid realities of the office and the bedroom. First performed in 1952 as The Pink Room” Ackland’s play initially caused unease due to its departure from the mood of post-war optimism; one critic even described it as a libel on the British people” A year earlier, London had hosted the Festival of Britain on the South Bank of the River Thames to celebrate social and cultural recovery after years of air raids and ration. Yet the perimeter of The Pink Room” is perpetually patrolled by a dead-eyed prostitute rumoured to attract 25 customers a night—hardly an image of renewal and positivity. Indeed, Ackland’s idea of hell wasn’t the austerity of war or the social attitudes of the time. The Soho of the 1940s is depicted as an island of sexual and cultural tolerance; in the La Vie en Rose even being German is considered acceptable. For Ackland, hell was the absence of other people. Characters unlucky enough to find themselves alone on stage almost immediately plunge into a state of despair: they feel secure only in the company of other. The group is immeasurably stronger than the psychological sum of its parts. At a time when the British were infamously reserved, candid expressions of loneliness found little applause, particularly at a time when the country was eager to look ahead to a more colourful and prosperous future. Absolute Hell” feels timely not only for its gloomy outlook and recognisably austere backdrop, but because third places are losing ground in modern cities. Social media platforms have become the primary forum for social conversation. At the same time, gentrification has pushed the price of drinking in bars away from what many young people could afford as a habit. London has lost since 2001. Many of those that haven’t been squeeze out by luxury property developers must cling on by squeez their customers. Marriner’s anxiety continue to resonate, too. His inability to impress his partner, his failure to find a sustainable career and the emasculating retreat to his mother’s spare bedroom will be uncomfortably familiar to a modern young audience. But the freedom he had to be himself in a welcoming third place, where everybody knew his name, may provoke some envy. Do you know that feeling when you’re in a crowd of people all drinking and shout, and nobody is listening and all at once you’re, as it were, drowne in a wave of love and understanding? he muse. For a split second you know your true identity. None of the other characters seems to be listening, but Marriner hardly seems bothere. For that is the key to a good third place: it belongs to everybody, and to nobody.
